channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2018 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sanctions Are Hurting North Korea. Can They Make Kim Give In?
item.media:description: A light show displayed a North Korean flag atop the empty Ryugyong Hotel in Pyongyang, the capital. New sanctions to stop its weapons programs have hurt the North, but the closed country is finding ways to cope.
item.description: The isolated North is finding ways to cope with tough new penalties. Is the economic pressure enough to get Kim Jong-un to give up his weapons?
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sale at Heathrow Terminal 1. Everything Must Go.
item.media:description: Terminal 1 at London’s Heathrow Airport in 1969, the year it was officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
item.description: The entire contents of the aged building, which opened in the 1960s, will be up for auction before it’s torn down to make way for Terminal 2’s expansion.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Long Before Cambridge Analytica, a Belief in the ‘Power of the Subliminal’
item.media:description: The offices of SCL Group in London. Its founder, Nigel Oakes, has stayed studiously in the background.
item.description: Decades ago, Nigel Oakes believed it was possible, using science, to influence human behavior on a mass scale. That ultimately led to data mining.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Who Is Miguel Díaz-Canel, Cuba’s New President?
item.media:description: Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez in line with his wife, Lis Cuesta, and local residents before voting in national and provincial elections in Santa Clara, Cuba, last month.
item.description: Most expect Cuba’s new president to be a leader of continuity after Raúl Castro. But he also has to figure out how to resuscitate Cuba’s economy.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte, Who Bristles at Foreign Critics, Has Begun Deporting Them
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte said he took “full responsibility” for the arrest of a 71-year-old Australian nun, a critic of his government who now faces deportation proceedings.
item.description: The Philippine president has overseen the deportation or detention of two foreigners who oppose his policies in recent days, including a 71-year-old nun.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: North Korean Leader Says ‘We No Longer Need’ Nuclear or Missile Tests
item.media:description: The arms announcement came one day after North and South Korea installed what officials said was the first-ever hotline between their top leaders.
item.description: The announcement by Kim Jong-un came less than a week before he meets with the president of South Korea.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Rome Journal: ‘Shut Up, Satan’: Rome Course Teaches Exorcism, Even by Cellphone
item.description: The annual seminar seeks to train an army of exorcists to confront spreading demonic forces. Behind it is a sense that the Roman Catholic Church has gone astray.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Swaziland’s King Wants His Country to Be Called eSwatini
item.media:description: King Mswati III of Swaziland.
item.media:credit: Taiwan Presidential Office, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.description: It means “land of the Swazis” in the local language. The name Swaziland dates to the period of British colonial rule, which ended in 1968.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Greek Court Upends Rules Limiting Migrants’ Movements
item.media:description: Asylum seekers from Syria and Afghanistan playing football last month at a camp on the Greek island of Lesbos.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The Council of State ruled that migrants arriving on Greek islands should no longer be held there while their asylum claims were assessed.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Libyan Strongman’s Illness Stokes Fears of a Succession Feud
item.media:description: Gen. Khalifa Hifter, who has not been seen publicly for weeks, in France last year.
item.description: Each day that Gen. Khalifa Hifter is absent from Libya with no clear report of his condition, concern grows of a violent fight to succeed him.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Suspects in Attack on Ex-Spy Are in Russia, U.K. Newspaper Reports
item.media:description: The former Russian spy Sergei V. Skripal during his trial in Russia in 2006. He and his daughter were the victims of a nerve agent attack in Britain last month.
item.description: Investigators identified the suspects by scanning flight manifests for passengers entering and exiting Britain, The Daily Telegraph reported. The police would not confirm the report.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Michael Cohen, North Korea, Avicii: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and BRENT MURRAY

item.title: Gaza Protest Draws Fewer People but Remains Deadly
item.media:description: A Palestinian protester during clashes with Israeli security forces near the border east of Gaza City on Friday.
item.description: Among four reported killed by Israeli snipers was a 15-year-old boy. Israel’s defense minister said there were fewer people but more “terror activity.”
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and IYAD ABUHEWEILA

item.title: From Janitor to Chief Justice: Could Joaquim Barbosa be Brazil’s Next President?
item.media:description: Joaquim Barbosa, center, who met this week with election officials in Brasília, is considering running for president of Brazil.
item.description: Brazil’s first black Supreme Court justice, a newcomer to politics, has emerged as a central figure in a race he has yet to formally join.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON

item.title: India’s A.T.M.s Are Running Out of Cash. Again.
item.media:description: A customer tries to use an ATM in New Delhi. India’s government says an unusual spurt in demand has caused a shortage of cash, but economists say it is primarily the government’s fault.
item.description: The shortage, caused by government policies, poses a challenge for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who was also responsible for India’s last cash crisis.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and VINDU GOEL

item.title: Nicaragua Roiled by Protests Over Social Security Benefits
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with the police in Managua, Nicaragua, this week during demonstrations against changes to the country’s social security program.
item.description: At least three people, including a police officer, have been killed in three days of sometimes violent demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Nobel Panel Admits Inquiry Found Sexual Misconduct, but Nothing Illegal
item.media:description: People gathered in Stockholm on Thursday in a show of support for Sara Danius, the permanent secretary of the Swedish Academy, who stepped down last Thursday.
item.description: Charges against Jean-Claude Arnault, a cultural arbiter, have rocked the Swedish Academy. It is forwarding to the police some results of its investigation.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON

item.title: A Canadian Terrorism Confession on a Times Podcast: the Canada Letter
item.media:description: Rukmini Callimachi at a church in western Mosul, Iraq, that had been converted into the headquarters of the Islamic State’s morality police.
item.description: In this week’s Canada Letter: a conversation with Rukmini Callimachi about covering terrorism and her new podcast which includes a startling confession.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Natalie Portman Backs Out of Israeli Award Ceremony
item.media:description: Natalie Portman has been very critical of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
item.description: The latest celebrity to opt out of an event in Israel over disagreements with its government, Ms. Portman cited her distress over “recent events” in Israel.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: A French Honor Not Always for the Honorable; Assad Returns His
item.media:description: A Syrian official, left, handing the Legion of Honor medal awarded to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria to a representative of the Romanian Embassy in Damascus on Thursday. Romania is representing France’s interests in Syria, and Mr. Assad returned the medal before France could withdraw the honor.
item.media:credit: Syrian Presidency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The Legion of Honor goes to luminaries in many fields — and also to some less-obvious figures. Noriega and Putin have been among the recipients.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: A Trace of Novichok on Your Salad?
item.media:description: Alexei Yakushev has introduced a sunflower oil called “Novichok.” The label describes it as “Recommended by the K.G.B.”
item.description: A farmer in Russia has introduced a sunflower oil named for the military-grade nerve agent used to poison a Russian former spy and his daughter in Britain.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW LUXMOORE

item.title: Kangaroo Pelted With Rocks Dies in Chinese Zoo, and Fury Flies
item.media:description: A 5-year-old male kangaroo at Fuzhou zoo in southeastern China, with a foot injury said to be from a visitor throwing a stone to make it jump. A 12-year-old female kangaroo died at the same zoo after being pelted with rocks.
item.description: Attacks on the animals in southeastern China have unleashed anger and bafflement about the behavior of visitors.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Thousands Evacuated in Berlin After World War II Bomb Is Found
item.media:description: The police in Germany blocked roads next to Berlin’s main train station on Friday during an evacuation prompted by the discovery of an unexploded bomb from World War II.
item.description: The 70-year-old explosive, which the Berlin police said had mostly likely been dropped by a British bomber, was found during construction north of the main train station.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Trump Criticizes OPEC, Calling Oil Prices ‘Artificially’ High
item.media:description: President Trump boarding Air Force One at Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday. He criticized OPEC on Friday, arguing that it “artificially” raised oil prices.
item.description: The president’s remarks came with gasoline prices at their highest point in three years after an effort by the oil cartel and Russia to restrain output.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Barclays Chief Executive Staley Fined Over Whistle-Blower Scandal
item.media:description: James E. Staley, the chief executive of Barclays, at Downing Street in London on January. He was fined on Friday over his attempt to unmask a whistle-blower within the bank.
item.description: The bank said that it will continue to stand by its leader, as it struggled to set aside years of lackluster results and management turmoil.
item.dc:creator: KATE KELLY

item.title: Seeking Foreign Money, G.O.P. Donor Pushed for Trump to Golf With Malaysian Premier
item.media:description: Elliott Broidy explored plans to force the exit from the United States of a Chinese billionaire and dissident, evidently to please Chinese allies in Malaysia.
item.media:credit: Alex J. Berliner/ABImages, via Associated Press
item.description: Documents reveal new details about the efforts of Elliott Broidy to exploit his White House ties. They also raise questions about whether Trump administration officials knew of his attempts.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Wells Fargo, North Korea, Cuba: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and BRENT MURRAY

item.title: Big Protests in South Africa Force Ramaphosa to End London Visit
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa was in London for his first visit to a meeting of Commonwealth leaders since February, when he replaced Jacob Zuma.
item.description: The new president, Cyril Ramaphosa, has pledged to curb corruption and increase economic growth — goals vital for the political survival of the governing African National Congress.
item.dc:creator: SELAM GEBREKIDAN

item.title: Missile Strikes Are Unlikely to Stop Syria’s Chemical Attacks, Pentagon Says
item.media:description: Planning for the strike of 105 missiles on three targets — chemical weapons storage and research facilities near Damascus and Homs — took nearly a full week.
item.description: A military intelligence report found that the Syrian government is expected to resume its chemical weapons program, despite President Trump saying “mission accomplished.” Here’s how the strike unfolded.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS GIBBONS-NEFF
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 3 Americans Held in North Korea: Who They Are and How They Got There
item.media:description: People walked away after paying respects at the statues of Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il at Mansu Hill in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Sunday.
item.description: President Trump says negotiators are “fighting very diligently” for three Korean-Americans — a businessman and two scholars — being held by Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: In a Trade War, China Might Boycott U.S. Goods. That Could Backfire.
item.media:description: A Nike store in Beijing. Many of the goods that Nike and other American companies produce are assembled by Chinese workers.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: State media have hinted that Beijing could weaponize its consumers in a trade war. But American brands are popular in China — and Chinese workers make many of their products.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE and ZHANG TIANTIAN

item.title: Four Masked Burglars Steal Jade and Gold Artifacts From Museum in England
item.media:description: The thieves smashed display cases at the Museum of East Asian Art in Bath, England, and fled in a sport utility vehicle, the police said.
item.description: Witnesses reported seeing the thieves break a first-floor window on Tuesday at the Museum of East Asian Art and steal items of “priceless” significance, the police said.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Hans Asperger Aided Nazi Child Euthanasia, Study Says
item.media:description: Hans Asperger in Vienna in 1971. According to a new report, Dr. Asperger participated in the Third Reich’s child-euthanasia program.
item.description: The autism researcher collaborated with the Third Reich and actively assisted in the killing of disabled children, a new report says.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: It Could Be Game Over for a Onetime King of Donkey Kong
item.media:description: Billy Mitchell in 2015. He criticized the decision to expunge his high score, saying, “This story is way, way more complicated than you could ever imagine.”
item.description: The million-point record of Billy Mitchell, the subject of a 2007 documentary, has been thrown out, and Steve Wiebe, his rival, claims “sweet victory.”
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA CARON

item.title: Trump Administration Seeks to Expand Sales of Armed Drones
item.media:description: Drones like the Reaper have been the workhorse and controversial symbol of the fight against insurgents in Afghanistan and the tribal regions of Pakistan.
item.media:credit: Lt. Col. Leslie Pratt/U.S. Air Force, via Associated Press
item.description: A day after President Trump promised to slash red tape involved in weapons sales, the administration announced new policies, but experts said they would do little to speed exports.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Fidel Died and Raúl Resigned, but Castros Still Hold Sway in Cuba
item.media:description: Fidel Castro, center, clasped hands with his brother, President Raúl Castro, right, and the second secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cuba, José Ramón Machado Ventura, at a party congress in Havana in 2016.
item.description: Stalwarts and heirs of the Communist revolution will help support — and scrutinize — Cuba’s new president, Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: If the World Economy Is Looking So Great, Why Are Global Policymakers So Gloomy?
item.media:description: The World Economic Outlook news conference at the headquarters of the International Monetary Fund in Washington on Wednesday. “The present good times will not last for long,” said Maurice Obstfeld, chief economist of the I.M.F.
item.description: As officials gather for the I.M.F. and World Bank convene in Washington, worries about trade and debt are building
item.dc:creator: NEIL IRWIN

item.title: Frenchman Is First in World to Get 2 Full Face Transplants
item.media:description: Jérôme Hamon, left, the first person to receive two full-face transplants, with Dr. Laurent Lantieri at the Georges-Pompidou European Hospital in Paris.
item.description: Jérôme Hamon, a bookseller who has a genetic disease, underwent a second transplant after his body rejected the first because he had taken an antibiotic for a cold.
item.dc:creator: TANGUY GARREL-JAFFRELOT

item.title: North Korea Drops Troop Demand, but U.S. Reacts Warily
item.media:description: American soldiers pulling dummies in Dongducheon, South Korea, this month.
item.description: North Korea’s leader will no longer demand that American troops leave South Korea, the South’s president said, but American officials dismissed the idea that it was a capitulation.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Macron Had a Big Plan for Europe. It’s Now Falling Apart.
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron speaking in Épinal, France, on Tuesday. Mr. Macron’s proposed European overhaul has been hamstrung by the results of elections in Germany and Italy.
item.description: A weakened Angela Merkel, a surge in Italian populism and unresolved Brexit issues have undermined the French president’s push to reinvigorate the E.U.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: For Faulting a Chinese Tonic, He Got 3 Months in Jail. Then Cheers.
item.media:description: Hongmao Medical Tonic, supposedly a curative blend of 67 ingredients, on sale at a pharmacy in Shanghai.
item.description: A doctor who suggested that a popular, alcohol-based tonic was dangerous was held for nearly 100 days. He emerged as a public hero.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Would You Pass the Green Card Marriage Interview?
item.media:description: Marrying an American citizen is considered a shortcut to getting a green card, but it’s not a guarantee.
item.description: Would your relationship stand up to the scrutiny of the American government? Take the test.
item.dc:creator: SHREEYA SINHA and SEAN PLAMBECK

item.title: International Herald Tribune: 1918: American Heroes Honored in France
item.media:description: Two American Lieutenants were awarded the French Croix de Guerre.
item.description: Two American lieutenants, one from Yale, the other from Harvard, received France’s Croix de Guerre for bringing down two German airplanes.
item.dc:creator: THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Damage to Great Barrier Reef From Global Warming Is Irreversible, Scientists Say
item.media:description: A diver surveying damaged coral in the Great Barrier Reef after a mass bleaching in 2016.
item.media:credit: XL Catlin Seaview Survey, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A huge heat wave killed 30 percent of the reef’s coral in 2016, and continuously high temperatures are preventing its recovery.
item.dc:creator: JACQUELINE WILLIAMS

item.title: What Movies to See (or Skip) in Australian Cinemas This April
item.media:description: From left, Steve Buscemi as Khrushchev, Adrian McLoughlin as Stalin (on the floor), Jeffrey Tambor as Malenkov, Dermot Crowley as Kaganovich and Simon Russell Beale as Beria in Armando Iannucci’s “The Death of Stalin.”
item.description: Not sure what movies to see in Australia this month? Let a New York Times critic help you with our film guide.
item.dc:creator: TACEY RYCHTER

item.title: Meet Me in Mongolia: How Aging Aircraft May Dictate Kim-Trump Venue
item.media:description: An Ilyushin Il-62, a Soviet airliner, in North Korea. The site options for the meeting between the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, and President Trump are limited.
item.description: Kim Jong-un is not known to have flown outside his country, and the question of his transportation complicates an already delicate and uncertain meeting.
item.dc:creator: ALI WATKINS

item.title: Life After Castro: Who Is Cuba’s Next President?
item.description: As Raúl Castro of Cuba steps down, Miguel Díaz-Canel Bermúdez steps up. Here’s a look at Mr. Castro’s handpicked successor and what’s ahead for the communist country.

item.title: North Korea, Southwest Airlines, Barbara Bush: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL
